result.execSummary:
The defendant Rhiana L. Lloyd was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: DEFENDANT TO REPORT FOR BOOKING AND SUBMIT DNA SAMPLE BY NO LATER THAN JANUARY 14, 2016.

DA Gerald Fox appears for the State.  Defendant appeared through her Attorney, Carly Sebion.  Pleading no contest to the charge.  $200 fine, plus costs.  Court questioned Attorney Sebion on defendant's understanding of the plea/sentencing.  Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily and intelligently entered her plea and waived her constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the plea.  Found guilty of the charge.  Court ordered $200.00 fine, plus costs.  Defendant to be booked and have DNA submitted by 1/14/16.
of plea/sentencing notice.  RTS.  not deliverable as addressed.  UTF
Plea/sentencing hearing at 12-21-2015 01:30 pm
DA Gerald Fox appears for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Sebion.  Have an agreement.  Set for plea/sentencing 12/21/15 at 1:30 PM
Status conference at 11-30-2015 03:00 pm

Until further order of the court, you shall have no contact, directly or indirectly, either personally, by mail, telephone or through any other person, except through your attorney, with any of the following individuals and/or businesses:    Wayside Tavern.  Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located, expect for employment purposes only.    As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.
